Adhola: Mac
English: Fire

English: Look, fire!

Adhola: Mac waŋo gi kipiny
English: Fire burns

Adhola: Watedo gi mac
English: Fire cooks

Adhola: Mac kelo ri wan lyetho
English: Fire gives warmth

Adhola: Mac miyo wan lero
English: Fire gives light

Adhola: Mac obedo gi maber
English: Fire is wonderful

Adhola: Aka ni gi men
English: And it is powerful

Adhola: Tedo
English: Cooking

Adhola: Agowo rabwo
English: I peel the potatoes

Adhola: Anyaro kabico
English: I chop a cabbage

Adhola: Agweno karoti
English: I grate the carrots

Adhola: Alwoko bijanjali
English: I wash the beans

Adhola: Aŋado nyaryeŋa
English: I cut the butternut

Adhola: Anyaro siku mawiki
English: I chop the spinach

Adhola: Mama ŋado katungulu
English: My mom chops the onions

Adhola: Katungulu maŋ oŋadi lunga i waŋan
English: Onions make me cry when they are chopped

Adhola: Jali Ma Bori Tektek Swa
English: A very tall man

Adhola: kweri pere oyido chieki swa
English: His hoe was too short

Adhola: Dhioti pere oyido ni pinyi swa
English: His doorway was too low

Adhola: Kitanda pere oyido cheiki swa
English: His bed was too short

Adhola: Gali pere oyido chieki swa
English: His bicycle was too short

Adhola: Jaali me oyido bori swa!
English: This man was too tall!

Adhola: Go oyiko furi kweri mabori swa
English: He made a very long hoe handle

Adhola: Go oyiko kitanda mabori swa
English: He made a very long bed

Adhola: Go onyiewo gali manitye malo swa
English: He bought a very high bicycle

Adhola: Go obedo i komi ma bori swa
English: He sat on a very high chair

Adhola: Go ochiemo gi wuma ma bori swa
English: He ate with a very long fork

Adhola: Go oweyo pecho pere to chako bedo iluli
English: He left his home and lived in a big forest

Adhola: Go obedo ma oro kweth
English: He lived for many years

Adhola: Dyel, Gwok Kodi Dhyaŋ
English: Goat, Dog, and Cow

Adhola: Cango cango Dyel, Gwok gi Dhyaŋ jo bedo mere matek swa
English: Goat, Dog, and Cow were great friends

Adhola: Ndir acel jo kidho woth i motoka
English: Oneday they went on a journey in a taxi

Adhola: Jo tundo kama joloro iye
English: They reached the end of their journey

Adhola: Jagwey motoka openjo jo cul ma woth
English: the river asked them to pay their fares

Adhola: Dhyaŋ oculo apere
English: Cow paid her fare

Adhola: Gwok oculo pesa ma thoth, rupir go oyido ongoye gi pesa ma thin
English: Dog paid a bit extra, because he did not have the correct money

Adhola: Jagwey motoka oyido chegin dwoko ri Gwok pesa pere ma odoŋ
English: The driver was about to give Dog his change

Adhola: Dyel ŋweco woko abwap ma ku culo apere
English: Goat ran away without paying anything

Adhola: Jagwey motoka omako nge swa
English:
The driver was very
annoyed

Adhola: Go otugila motoka to kadho ma ku dwoko ri Gwok pesa pere ma odong
English: He drove away without giving Dog his change

Adhola: Meno, ama omiyo kiri konon, fodi Gwok ŋweco ryemo motoka ni woleŋo iye waŋe
English: That is why, even today, Dog runs towards a car to peep inside

Adhola: Go rango jagwey motoka ma ku dwoko ri go pesa pere ma odoŋ
English:
He is looking for the driver who owes him his
change

Adhola: Dyel ŋweco aŋweca ka owinjo mor ma motoka
English: Goat runs away from the sound of a car

Adhola: Go lworo ni ile mako go rupir ndir no ku culo jagwey motoka pesa ma woth
English: She is afraid she will be arrested for not paying her fare

Adhola: Dhyaŋ ki dew ri go kwoŋ motokin
English:
And Cow is not bothered when a car is
coming

Adhola: Dhyaŋ gale a gala ka ŋado ngudo
English: Cow takes her time crossing the road

Adhola: Oŋeyo ni oculo pesa pere mawoth je
English: she knows she paid her fare in full

Adhola: Nyathi Ma Nyakare
English: Donkey Child

Adhola: To aneno dhako ma yac ma omako iye
English: Then I saw  that it was a heavily pregnant woman

Adhola: Dhako no to nywolo punda
English: The woman gave birth to a donkey

Adhola: Ji jo penjere ni, "Wa no tim nedi?"
English: People asked themselves, "What shall we do?"

Adhola: To dhako no paro ni, "A la timere nedi gi nyathi me?"
English: She wondered what to do with this awkward child

Adhola: Rumacen, dhako no oyere to maro nyathi pere
English: Finally, the woman accepted and loved her child

Adhola: Nyathi no odongo, obedo ma dwoŋ, ma odhyero kir min tiŋo
English: The child grew and grew until he could no longer fit on his mother’s back

Adhola: Min obedo gi gut
English: The mother was sad

Adhola: Nyathi pere bende omako nge to gweyo go
English: The child also became so angry and kicked her

Adhola: Oŋweco woko munyo oneno min opodho piny
English: He became so angry that, one day, he kicked his mother to the ground

Adhola: odoŋ kende
English: He was alone

Adhola: Ool to kec oneko
English: He was tired and hungry

Adhola: Munyo nyathi punda ocew, oneno jal moro ocungo dho bothe
English: Donkey woke up to find a strange old man staring down at him

Adhola: Ndir acel, jo idho wi got moro kir malo, jo ol to jo podho nindo
English: One day, they went to the mountain top, they were  tired and fell asleep

Adhola: Munyo nyathi punda ocew, onwaŋo ni nitye kende kendo
English: When donkey child woke up, he found that he ws alone again

Adhola: Nyathi punda obedo gi gut
English: Donkey child was sad

Adhola: Owotho ka gi kaca rango min
English: He walked here and there looking for his mother

Adhola: Nyathi punda oneno dhano moro to penjere ni
English: Donkey Child saw someone and asked himself

Adhola: Wok i ndiri no nyathi punda gi min jo bedo ka nyacel
English: The donkey child and his mother have grown together

Adhola: Tiŋo min to wotho gi ne
English: Nowadays the mother walks with him

Adhola: Ywomirok Bothi Adhadha
English: Holidays with grandmother

Adhola: Odongo gi Apiyo jobedo gi ba jo i tindi madwoŋ
English: Odongo and Apiyo lived in the city with their father

Adhola: Jo bedo ka jo kiyo akiya ywomirok
English: They looked forward to the holidays

Adhola: Ki rupir sikulu i lacego, to rupir jowanya kidho lyewo adha jo
English: Not just because school was closed, but because they went to visit their grandmother

Adhola: Go bedo yoloka pa jokitoga ger gi nam madwoŋ
English: She lived in a fishing village near a large lake

Adhola: Odongo gi Apiyo jo sangala swa rupir hongo otundo ma kidho lyewo adha jo kendo
English: Odongo and Apiyo were excited because it was time to visit their grandmother again

Adhola: Wor ma otelo jo tweyo migugu pa jo to jo yikere ma woth ma kidho loka pa adha jo
English: The night before, they packed their bags and got ready for the long journey to her village

Adhola: Nindo kumako waŋ jo aka jo luwo kwoŋ lyewo adha jo wor gi pi
English: They could not sleep and talked the whole night about the holiday

Adhola: Jo mondo yawere mere kadho padha jo i mutoka pa ba jo
English: Early the next morning, they left for the village in their father’s car

Adhola: Ogwey gi jo motoka kalo gote, ogwange ma dudi gi ndelin majan
English: They drove past mountains, wild animals and tea plantations

Adhola: Jo kwano motokin aka jowero
English: They counted cars and sang songs

Adhola: Rumacen nyithindho jo ol to jo podho nindo
English: After a while, the children were tired and fell asleep

Adhola: Ba jo ocewo jo munyo jo tundo loka ago
English: Father woke up Odongo and Apiyo as they arrived in the village

Adhola: Jo nwaŋo adha jo, Nyajaruya, ywomere i tyendi yath i par
English: They found Nyajaruya, their grandmother, resting on a mat under a tree

Adhola: Nyajaruya osangala gi jo, orwako jo i ot to mielo thoko dier ot
English: Nyajaruya welcomed them into the house and danced around the room singing with joy

Adhola: Nyikwaye jo miyo go mic ma jo kelo wok i tindi madwoŋ
English: Her grandchildren were excited to give her the presents they brought from the city

Adhola: Odongo owaco ni, "Tel yawo mic paran"
English: "First open my gift",said Odongo

Adhola: Apiyo bende owaco ni, "Be, tel gi aparan ayino!"
English: "No, my gift first!", said Apiyo

Adhola: Munyo Nyajaruwa ocowo yawo mic je, omiyo nyikwaye silwany i kula ma nyanono pa jo
English: After she opened the presents, Nyajaruya blessed her grandchildren in a traditional way

Adhola: Odongo gi Apiyo to jowok kadho tuko
English: Then Odongo and Apiyo went outside

Adhola: Jo riemo ombutuku gi winyin
English: They chased butterflies and birds

Adhola: Jo idho yen to jo tuko i pi ma nam
English: They climbed trees and splashed in the water of the lake

Adhola: Munyo piny oyutho jo dok peco cemo m’othieno
English: When it was dark they returned to the house for dinner

Adhola: Jo podho nindo mafodi jo kucowo kada cemo!
English: Before they could finish eating, they were falling asleep!

Adhola: Yawere mere ba nyithindho no ogweyo mutoka pere dok i tindi madwoŋ to weyo jo gi adha jo
English: The next day, the children’s father drove back to the city leaving them with Nyajaruya

Adhola: Odongo gi Apiyo jo konyo adha jo gi tic ma peco
English: Odongo and Apiyo helped their grandmother with household chores

Adhola: Jo kulo pi to jo dimo yen
English: They fetched water and firewood

Adhola: Jo coko toŋgwendi to joŋweto fufa
English: They collected eggs from the chickens and picked greens from the garden

Adhola: Nyajaruya ofonjo nyikwaye guro kwon mayom macamere gi fufa
English: Nyajaruya taught her grandchildren to make soft ugali to eat with stew

Adhola: Onyutho jo kite matedo micere gi cak nazi ma camera gi rec abula
English: She showed them how to make coconut rice to eat with roast fish

Adhola: Odikini acel Odongo okidho kwayo dhok p’adhamere
English: One morning, Odongo took his grandmother’s cows to graze

Adhola: Jo donjo i ndelo pa jager
English: They ran onto a neighbour’s farm

Adhola: Won ndelo omako nge gi Odongo
English: The farmer was angry with Odongo

Adhola: Obwoko go ni ladoŋ gi dhoki rupir jo camo cemo pere
English: He threatened to keep the cows for eating his crops

Adhola: Wok ndelo no Odongo ogwoko dhoki timo banja kendo
English: After that day, the boy made sure that the cows did not get into trouble again

Adhola: Ndelo man nyithindho jokidho i kisiya gi adha jo
English: On another day, the children went to the marketplace with Nyajaruya

Adhola: Go oyido nitie gi kitandilo m’atana iye fufa, sukari gi sabuni
English: She had a stall selling vegetables, sugar and soap

Adhola: Apiyo omaro waco ri jonyew welo ma gigipiny
English: Apiyo liked to tell customers the price of items

Adhola: Odongo oyido tweyo gigipiny m’otiek nyewo
English: Odongo would pack the items that customers bought

Adhola: I cowe mere jo madho cai kanyacel
English: At the end of the day they drank chai tea together

Adhola: Jo konyo adha jo gi kwano pesa m’olimo
English: They helped grandmother to count the money she earned

Adhola: Mayot yot ywomirok orumo aka oripo ni nyithindho no jo wodoki i tindi pa jo
English: But too soon the holidays were over and the children had to go back to the city

Adhola: Nyajaruwa omiyo Odongo junga to miyo Apiyo sweta
English: Nyajaruya gave Odongo a cap and Apiyo a sweater

Adhola: Otweyo ri jo kit cemo ma camo iyo
English: She packed food for their journey

Adhola: Munyo ba jo obino omo jo, oyido jo kumito dok
English: When their father came to fetch them, they did not want to leave

Adhola: Nyithindho jo kwayo adha jo dok gi jo i tindi madwoŋ
English: The children begged Nyajaruya to go with them to the city

Adhola: Obwonjo to waco ni, "Asa ti ma kidho i tindi madwoŋ"
English: She smiled and said, "I am too old for the city"

Adhola: Alabedo ka akur win bino thurin kendo
English: I will be waiting for you to come to my village again

Adhola: Odongo gi Apiyo jopodho i kor adha jo ma joridho matek aka jo sewila go
English: Odongo and Apiyo both hugged her tightly and said goodbye

Adhola: Munyo Odongo gi Apiyo jo dok i sikulu jo lyesaÂ ri wadi gin kwoŋ kwo ma calo
English: When Odongo and Apiyo went back to school they told their friends about life in the village

Adhola: Nyithindho megi jo paro ni kwo ma tindi ber
English: Some children felt that life in the city was good

Adhola: Megi jo paro ni calo ber loyo
English: Others felt that the village was better

Adhola: To mâ€™oloyo aloya swa kis dhano oyeyo ni Odongo gi Apiyo jo nitie gi adha jo maber mâ€™oasere!
English: But most of all, everyone agreed that Odongo and Apiyo had a wonderful grandmother!

Adhola: Gweno Kodi Ongongolo
English: Chicken and Millipede

Adhola: Gweno kodi Ongongolo oyido mere
English: Chicken and Millipede were friends

Adhola: To oyido ju tere pyemo gi achieli kwong jo
English: But they were always competing with each other

Adhola: Ndelo achieli ju yiko tuko mupira nyaka juneni jatuko maberi
English: One day they decided to play football to see who the best player was

Adhola: Jukadho ikisawe toju chako tuko pajo
English: They went to the football field and started their game

Adhola: Gweno oyido ni piyopiyo to Ongongolo oyido nipiyo swa
English: Chicken was fast, but Millipede was faster

Adhola: Gweno ogeyo mupira bori to Ongongolo ogweyo bori swa
English: Chicken kicked far, but Millipede kicked further

Adhola: Gweno to chako winjo nywowiroki
English: Chicken started to feel grumpy

Adhola: Juyiko tuko makitewa neno ngata oloyi
English: They decided to play a penalty shoot-out

Adhola: Ongongolo obedo jamaki gole
English: First Millipede was goal keeper

Adhola: Gweno otewa gole achieli
English: Chicken scored only one goal

Adhola: Nyo totundo sawa pa Gweno ma makuro gole
English: Then it was the chicken’s turn to defend the goal

Adhola: Ongongolo ogweyo mupira totewa
English: Millipede kicked the ball and scored

Adhola: Ongongolo oketa mupira totewa
English: Millipede dribbled the ball and scored

Adhola: Ongongolo ogoyo mupira giwiye totewa
English: Millipede headed the ball and scored

Adhola: Ongongolo otewa gole abich!
English: Millipede scored five goals

Adhola: Gweno omako nge ni go ofiriwa
English: Chicken was furious that she lost

Adhola: Go oyido obedo jakifiriwa marachi swa
English: She was a very bad loser

Adhola: Ongongolo ochako nyero rupiri mere pere oyido timo ginyero
English: Millipede started laughing because his friend was making such a fuss

Adhola: Gweno omako nge to yawo dhoke malachi swa to mwonyo Ongongolo
English: Chicken was so angry that she opened her beak wide and swallowed the millipede

Adhola: Munyo Gweno oyido doki pecho, go oromo gi yoki Ongongolo
English: As Chicken was walking home, she met Mother Millipede

Adhola: Yoki Ongongolo openjo ni ineno ye nyathi parani?
English: Mother Millipede asked, "Have you seen my child?"

Adhola: Gweno ku wacho gimoro jye
English: Chicken didn’t say anything

Adhola: Yoki Ongongolo obedo gi rembo
English: Mother Millipede was worried

Adhola: Nyaka to yoki Ongongolo winjo dwondo jo mathini
English: Then Mother Millipede heard a tiny voice

Adhola: Konyani Mama dwondi jo oywaki
English: â€œHelp me mom!â€ cried the voice

Adhola: Yoki Ongongolo ongiyo thubongi go to winjo gi kikangasa swa
English: Mother Millipede looked around and listened carefully

Adhola: Dwondi jo owoki iyii Gweno
English: The voice came from inside the chicken

Adhola: Yoki Ongongolo okoko, ori meni perini ma were omiyini nyathi paran! Ongongolo nyalo wotho ngweche marachi swa makibilere
English: Mother Millipede shouted, â€œUse your special power my child!â€ Millipedes can make a bad smell and a terrible taste

Adhola: Gweno ochako kichiroki pa two
English: Chicken began to feel ill

Adhola: Gweno ochukere
English: Chicken burped

Adhola: Nyaka to mwonyo gi ngulo
English: Then she swallowed and spat

Adhola: Nyaka to jiro gi wolo
English: Then she sneezed and coughed

Adhola: Munyo owolo
English: And coughed

Adhola: Ongongolo ochali pa oyido kimiti
English: The millipede was disgusting!

Adhola: Gweno owolo nyuka owolo woko Ongongolo iyii go
English: Chicken coughed until she coughed out the millipede that was in her stomach

Adhola: Yoki Ongongolo gi nyathi pere jurweta malo iwi yathi pondo
English: Mother Millipede and her child crawled up a tree to hide

Adhola: Woki isawa no, Gwendi kodi Ongongolini jubedo jukwori
English: From that time, chickens and millipedes were enemies

Adhola: Jo calo mawan jo jolo dhako no to doŋ both wan
English: My village people welcomed that woman and she remained with us.

Adhola: I dyer wor dhako no okoko ni, "Nyathi! Eno nyathi wok"
English: In the middle of the night that woman shouts that, "Child! Yes the child is coming out"

Adhola: Aneno dhano to akaŋasa go tek tek
English: I saw that woman and I analyzed her very well

Adhola: Ji jo ŋweco kwoŋgo
English: People ran away from her

Adhola: Jalo otiŋo go to dok gine peco pere
English: That man carried her and took her to his  home

Adhola: Nyathi punda otiŋo jalo i gongo munyo otegino
English: A small donkey carried that man on its back when it grew mature.

Adhola: Afoyo I Tiendi Yath
English: The Rabbit under the Tree

Adhola: Afoyo oyido nindo i tiendi mutundwa
English: Rabbit was sleeping under an apple tree

Adhola: Mutundwa acel opodho wok malo
English: An apple fell down from a branch

Adhola: Owinjo ka gimoro waco ni, “Ringi Afoyo, ringi!”
English: A voice said, "Run Rabbit run!"

Adhola: Go ocew piyo piyo to ŋweco ma dwir
English: She woke up quickly and ran away with great speed.

Adhola: Oromo gi gweno.
English: She met Chicken.

Adhola: To gweno penjo go ni, “I ringo aŋo?”
English: "Why are you running?" asked Chicken.

Adhola: Afoyo odwoko ni, “Akuya ran.
English: Rabbit replied, "I don't know.

Adhola: Awinjo awinja gimoro podho to gimoro waco ni, Ringi Afoyo ringi!“

Adhola: Joromo gi Pus.

Adhola: Pus openjo jo ni, “Wi ringo aŋo?“

Adhola: Jo romo gi nyath ma nyiyac ma gweyo gal to penjo jo ni, “Wi ringo aŋo?“
English: Then they met the boy riding the bicycle and he asked, "Why are you running?''

Adhola: To ogwange jodwokoi ni, “Wakuya ri wan. "

Adhola: Wawinjo gima Afoyo owaco, aka go bende kuya.

Adhola: To aŋata awaco ni Ringi Afoyo ringi.

Adhola: Amaro kisoma.
English: I like to read.

Adhola: Nga manyalo kisoma?
English: Who can I read to?

Adhola: Nyamerani nindo.
English: My sister is asleep

Adhola: Mama parani kodi athatha ju ngoye gi sawa.
English: My mother and grandmother are busy.

Adhola: My father and grandfather are busy.

Adhola: I can read to myself!
English: Asoma ri awoni!

Adhola: Who can I read to?

Adhola: Kere mupongi gwoki mathini
English: Fat King Thin Dog

Adhola: Me kere mupongi.
English: This is a fat king.

Adhola: Kere mupongi pere gwoki  mathini
English: The fat king has a thin dog.

Adhola: Kere mupongi kodi gwoki pere mathini ju kadho wothi.
English: The fat king and his thin dog go for a walk.

Adhola: Gwoki oneno winyo
English: The dog sees a bird.

Adhola: Gwoki ngwecho kaluwo winyo.
English: The dog runs after the bird.

Adhola: Kere reimo gwoki
English: The king runs after the dog.

Adhola: To ju ngwecho angwecha
English: They run and run.

Adhola: To ju ngwecho angwecha ma ndelo muromo.
English: They run and run for many days.

Adhola: Kere tomako gwoki.
English: The king catches the dog.

Adhola: Nyo same kere mupongi nyo thini
English: Now the fat king is thin.

Adhola: Amito meno!
English: I Want That One!

Adhola: Obedo ndelo ma ywomirok ri Amma.
English: It was a holiday for Amma.

Adhola: Go oyido soma kitabo.
English: She was reading a book.

Adhola: Anil oywomere bende.
English: Anil had a holiday too.

Adhola: Goyido mito timo .... gimoro!
English: He wanted to do.... SOMETHING!

Adhola: Anil owacho ni' Amma, amito neno gima nitye ibokisi manya bululu no'.
English: “Amma, I want to see what is in that blue box!” said Anil.

Adhola: Amma owacho ni 'Anil choni'.
English: “Later, Anil,” said Amma.

Adhola: Anil oketho situli iwi komi.
English: Anil put a stool over a chair.

Adhola: Go oyidho malo kwanyo bokisi agoni pinyi.
English: He climbed up to get the box down.

Adhola: Amma owacho ni'Anil, beee beee! kimeno! bokisere jye jula podho iwiyi wani!'
English: “No, no! Not that one! All the boxes on top of that will fall on our heads, Anil!” said Amma.

Adhola: Anil omako nge swa.
English: Anil was very angry.

Adhola: Goyido omako nge gi mini.
English: He was angry with his mother.

Adhola: Amma owacho ni,' biye wadhi ikatale anwangi rini gimoro'.
English: “Come, let’s go to the market and get you something,” said Amma.

Adhola: Anil odongi mumako nge kiri munyo ju kadho ikatale.
English: Anil was very angry even after they went to the market.

Adhola: Go owacho ni, 'amito meno,' munyo go kimo muchungwa.
English: “I want that one!” he said, pointing at an orange.

Adhola: Jakitana duka owacho ni,' beee beee kimeno! muchungwini jula podho pinyi.
English: “No, no, not that one! The fruits will all fall down!” said the shopkeeper.

Adhola: Anil owacho ni,' amito kitabo no'.
English: “I want that book!” said Anil.

Adhola: Jakitana duka owacho ni ' beee beee kimeno'
English: “No, no, not that one!” said the shopkeeper.

Adhola: teri me'.
English: “Take this one.”

Adhola: Anil okoko ni,"amito meno" noki oywayi sumbusa malo iki kitandalo.
English: “I want that one!” shouted Anil, almost pulling out a samosa from a high stack of samosas.

Adhola: Jakitana duka owacho ni,' beee beee kimeno achikini teteli.
English: “No, no, not that one!” warned the shopkeeper.

Adhola: Sumbusa parani jye jula podho ilowo!
English: All my samosas will fall to the ground!

Adhola: Anil oluwo malo swa, amito meno!
English: “I want that one!” said Anil loudly.

Adhola: Go nyo same winjo marachi swa.
English: He was now in a very, very bad mood.

Adhola: Jakitana bumuli owacho ni,' beee beee kimeno!'
English: “No, no, not that one!” said the flower seller.

Adhola: ikiri maki  jo!
English: Don’t touch them!

Adhola: jula neri.
English: They will wilt.

Adhola: Onyo same, Anil oyido ywaki malo swa.
English: By now, Anil was crying loudly.

Adhola: Kisi dhano moro jye oyido ngiyo Anil.
English: Everyone was looking at Anil.

Adhola: Ityendi kitanda parani
English: Under my bed

Adhola: I chewi wori munyo awinjo riyo.
English: I wake up at night feeling thirsty.

Adhola: Amito nwango pii.
English: I want to get some water.

Adhola: To achako rango sapato parani,
English: I start looking for my slippers under the bed.

Adhola: Awi were parani!
English: Oh my God!

Adhola: kworo nitye ityendi kitanda parani.
English: There is a tiger under my bed.

Adhola: Nyo same atimi ango?
English: Now what should I do?

Adhola: Alwongi mama?
English: Should I call Ma?

Adhola: To ka kworo oywaki?
English: What if the tiger roars?

Adhola: Akadhi anindi?
English: Should I just go back to sleep?

Adhola: To kole nindo ongoye iwangani doko.
English: But I am not sleepy any more.

Adhola: Kikenyo to  dhano ketho machi.
English: Then someone turns on the light.

Adhola: Mama ochungo idhioti.
English: Ma is standing at the door.

Adhola: ango mutimere amara parani
English: What happened dear?

Adhola: Mama openjo ni,' ilwongani?
English: Did you call me? asks Ma.

Adhola: To achimo yubongi kworo.
English: I point towards the tiger.

Adhola: Mama ogungo to ywayo kworo woko woki ityendi kitanda!
English: Ma bends and pulls the tiger out from under the bed!

Adhola: Neni, me ki kworo.
English: Hey, this is no tiger.

Adhola: me sweta parani manitye gi rangi ma nya tongeno muruwere gi macholi.
English: This is my thick yellow and black sweater.

Adhola: Mapesini mere pilini pa wangi kworo.
English: Its buttons shine like a tiger's eyes.

Adhola: Nyingi nyathi lyec oyido Golu.
English: The little elephant's name was Golu.

Adhola: Go oyido onginere pa bul
English: He was as round as a drum.

Adhola: Nyathi afwoyo oyido ilwongo ni Chhotu.
English: The little rabbit was called Chhotu

Adhola: Go ochali pa mupira ma famba.
English: He looked like a ball of cotton.

Adhola: Ju tuko kanyachieli.
English: They played together.

Adhola: Ndelo achieli, Golu owacho ni,' watuki tuko manyien kononi'.
English: One day, Golu said, “Let’s play a new game today.”

Adhola: bedi pinyi.
English: You sit down.

Adhola: Chhotu owacho ni, 'Ala pye idyo ngeyini ka aayi dichieli'.
English: I’ll land on your back in one flying leap,” said Chhotu.

Adhola: Golu obedo pinyi.
English: Golu sat down.

Adhola: Chottu okadho kama bori swa.
English: Chhotu took a mighty leap.

Adhola: Thump! opye idyongei Golu.
English: Thump! He landed on Golu’s back.

Adhola: Golu onyero towacho ni,' nyo safari paran.'
English: Golu  laughed and said, “My turn now. "

Adhola: Bedi pinyi ala pye idyongeini'.
English: You sit down and I will leap on your back.”

Adhola: Inii!
English: “You!”

Adhola: Eeeyiii, anii.
English: Yes, me.

Adhola: Chottu openjo ni,' inyalo nedi timo ngino'.
English: “How can you do that?” asked Chhotu.

Adhola: Golu onyutho go ni,' amma'.
English: "Like this!" Golu showed him.

Adhola: Nazi kweth owki iwi Golu.
English: A shower of coconuts came down on Golu’s head.

Adhola: Go ongwecho woko gi tyende mupongi gi bwoki.
English: He ran away on fat legs, scared.

Adhola: Nazi achieli mathini opodho iwi Chhotu.
English: One small coconut fell on Chhotu.

Adhola: Sawa matuko
English: Playtime

Adhola: Nyathi gwoki pa Ammu
English: Ammu's Puppy

Adhola: Ammu oyido ongoye gi nyathi gwoki.
English: Ammu did not have a puppy.

Adhola: To go owacho ri kisi dhano isomero ni go nitye gine.
English: But she told everyone in school that she did.

Adhola: Go owacho ri Venu ni, "nyathi gwoki parani ilwongo ni Shankar".
English: "My puppy’s name is Shankar," she told Venu.

Adhola: Owacho ri Abdul ni, "Shankar chamo malapi".
English: "Shankar eats bananas," she told Abdul.

Adhola: Owacho ri Kumari ni, "Shankar choli".
English: "Shankar is black," she told Kumari.

Adhola: Owacho ri Unni ni, Shankar tuko mupira kodani."
English: "Shankar plays ball with me," she told Unni.

Adhola: Onyo Venu, Abdul, Kumari kodi Unni to juwacho ri Ammu nike ju labino pecho.
English: So Venu, Abdul, Kumari, and Unni told Ammu that they would come home.

Adhola: To ju neno Shankar.
English: To see Shankar.

Adhola: Ammu oyengo wiye.
English: Ammu shook her head.

Adhola: ju penjo ni irango.
English: They asked why

Adhola: Ammu owacho ni rupiri Shankar nigi bwoki ka oneno dwoli ji.
English: "Because Shankar is scared of crowds," said Ammu.

Adhola: Kumari to wacho ni ,"kale walatuko gi go kisi dhano achiele achiele".
English: "Then we’ll play with him one by one," said Kumari.

Adhola: Ammu owacho ni, "wiki nyali".
English: "You can’t," Ammu said.

Adhola: Unni openjo ni, "irango".
English: "Why?" asked Unni.

Adhola: Ammu owacho ni ,"ruprir wakadho wothi ye kononi."
English: "Because we’re going out today," said Ammu.

Adhola: Abdul owacho ni "nyo kale walabino dikini."
English: "Then we’ll come tomorrow," said Abdul.

Adhola: Venu owacho ni "wala kelo rigo malapi."
English: "We’ll bring bananas for him," said Venu.

Adhola: Kumari owacho ni "wala tuko gi go ngata achiele achiele."
English: "We’ll play with him one by one," said Kumari.

Adhola: Ammu owacho ni "kale."
English: "Okay," said Ammu.

Adhola: Go ku ngeyo gira awacha mani.
English: She didn’t know what else to say.

Adhola: Pinyin no, Ammu openjo Achan ka oyido nyalo nyewo rigo nyathi gwoki.
English: That evening, Ammu asked Achan if he would buy a puppy for her.

Adhola: Achan owacho ni, "wala neno."
English: "We’ll see," said Achan.

Adhola: Ammu owacho ni," amito ma piyopiyo."
English: "But it’s urgent," said Ammu.

Adhola: Achan onyero.
English: Achan laughed

Adhola: Ammu kuchamo chiemo ma othieno.
English: Ammu didn’t eat dinner.

Adhola: Go obedo pa ngata two.
English: She felt sick.

Adhola: Go kumito paro kwong dikini.
English: She didn’t want to think about tomorrow.

Adhola: Odikini
English: A fever!

Adhola: Amma owacho ni," dongi pecho."
English: Stay at home today, Amma said.

Adhola: To Ammu keng kisoma.
English: So Ammu skipped school.

Adhola: Go onindo ikanindo ma ndelo gipi.
English: She lay in bed all day.

Adhola: Go ku bwonjo kada.
English: She didn’t smile at all.

Adhola: Gima go ochamo obedo kitole ma mugati kende.
English: All she ate was a slice of bread.

Adhola: cango, cango, yo loka Paracam obedo jal m'ilwoŋo ni Otoyo
English: Greedy Otoyo

Adhola: Cango, cango, yo loka Paracam obedo jal m'ilwoŋo ni Otoyo
English: A long time ago, in the village of Nyamani, there lived a man known as Otoyo

Adhola: Go omaro cemo swa
English: Otoyo liked to eat very much

Adhola: Ma tektek mere go omaro camo riŋo
English: He especially liked to eat meat

Adhola: Ndir acel, rwoth ma loka no olwoŋo jo piny pere je kidho i kalima ma nywomirok pa wode
English: One day, the chief of the village invited all the villagers to his son's wedding

Adhola: Otoyo doko owinjo ka ji luwo kwoŋ kalima ma nywomirok man ma nitie loka ma ger m'ilwoŋo ni Paracuc
English: Then Otoyo heard people talking about another wedding party in a nearby village called Paracuc

Adhola: Otoyo oparo swa ni, “Kalima ario i ndelo acel!“
English: “Two parties on the same day!” Otoyo thought

Adhola: Otoyo won oluwere ni, “Aripo bedo i kalima ario je.“
English: “I must attend both parties,” Otoyo said to himself

Adhola: “Kutho a le telo kidho Paracuc aka nyaka adwoki Paracam.
English: “I will first walk to Paracuc  and then come back to Nyamani.”

Adhola: Otoyo omondo cew odikini to wotho kidho Paracuc
English: Otoyo woke up early in the morning and walked to Paracuc  village

Adhola: Munyo otundo oneno ni jotedo oyido nyaka jotedo
English: When he arrived, he saw that the cooks were still preparing the food

Adhola: To Otoyo yero ni, “A le gik cen Paracam aka anodwoki rumacen.“
English: “I will go back to Nyamani and return here later,” Otoyo decided

Adhola: Otoyo owotho dok Paracam munyo geno ni lanwaŋo riŋo ocek
English: Otoyo walked back to Nyamani hoping to find the meat ready

Adhola: Kare no kec neko go
English: He was now hungry

Adhola: To munyo otundo onwaŋo jono bende fodi jotedo cemo
English: But when he arrived, people there were also still preparing the food

Adhola: To Otoyo paro ni, “Munyo nende aay Paracuc oyido jocako tedo
English: “When I left Paracuc  they were starting to cook,” he thought

Adhola: Ripo bedo ni cemo no otieko cek pama.“
English: “The food must be ready now.”

Adhola: Ameno Otoyo doko owotho to gik Paracuc
English: So Otoyo walked back to Paracuc

Adhola: Kec oyido nyo neko go maa
English: He was now very hungry

Adhola: Munyo Otoyo otundo Paracuc kendo, ji oyido jocowo cemo
English: By the time Otoyo got to Paracuc , people had already eaten

Adhola: Wendo yido jomiyo mweha gi jamweha mic
English: Guests were giving presents to the bride and the groom

Adhola: Otoyo kobedo gi mic ma omiy
English: Otoyo did not have a gift to give

Adhola: Oyido go omito cemo kende
English: He only wanted to eat

Adhola: Otoyo owinjo malith swa nwaŋo ni okeŋ cemo
English: Otoyo was most disappointed about missing the food

Adhola: Owire gik yu Paracam
English: He decided to walk back to Nyamani village

Adhola: Owotho moth paka oyido kec neko aka doko ool
English: He was hungry and tired and walked very slowly.

Adhola: Munyo otundo Paracam oyido ji jowero aka jo mielo
English: When he arrived at Nyamani village, people were singing and dancing

Adhola: Oyido jo tieko camo cemo je!
English: They had already eaten all the food!

Adhola: Munyo Otoyo owinjo ni cemo orumo, opodho to tho atha
English: When he heard that there was no food, Otoyo fainted

Adhola: Okeŋ riŋo ma kalima ario je
English: He had missed meat from both parties

Adhola: Munyo ocerino omiy go nyuka nyaka mathin i kikombe
English: When he recovered, he got some porridge in a small cup!

Adhola: Kir konon Otoyo fodi kec neko aneka
English: Otoyo walked home again, still hungry

Adhola: Bul
English: Drum

Adhola: Bul obedo thum maber swa i piny mawan wok con
English: The drum has always been an important musical instrument in our community

Adhola: Wa maro bunde!
English: We love drums!

Adhola: Wa kuro bunde ma kite ma opokere opokere: madongo, m'oripripo gima'dundo
English: We have drums of different sizes: big, medium-sized and small

Adhola: Wa goyo bunde gi ludhe kosa gi lweti wan
English: We play drums using beaters, or with our fingers

Adhola: Wa goyo bunde ndir je ri atoŋa ma opokere opokere
English: We play drums for various reasons

Adhola: Wa goyo bunde gi wer, miel, kalima kosa teko
English: We play drums with songs and dances, for feasts and in bad times

Adhola: Bunde loko wer maloŋo, ico ji miel aka kelo siem i kalima
English: Drums enrich songs and make people want to dance and make ceremonies colourful

Adhola: Wagoyo bunde i kalima ma opokere opokere pakacwoko nyingi nyithindho, nywomirok, camo misiya, kosa yawo rut
English: We play drums during ceremonies for marriage and child naming, celebrating a new harvest or a twin birth.

Adhola: Wa goyo bunde ma tito rem kodi lwoŋo ji ka lielopodho ri wan
English: We sound drums to announce grief and call people when death occurs

Adhola: Wa goyo bunde ma lwoŋo ji yiko waŋ pi, doyo royo, kosa gero ot ri ŋat ma oti aka odamba
English: We sound drums to call people to clean wells, clear roads, or to build a hut for a needy old person

Adhola: Ka okwal dhok i piny mawan, i goyo bunde ma lwoŋo ji
English: We sound drums to call people when cattle are stolen in our village

Adhola: Ka romo le bedo i tindi pa rwoth bunde kworo ywak ma choko ji
English: We sound drums to gather people for meetings at our chief's palace

Adhola: Bunde lwoŋo ji kidho i odi Were i hola je ma lamo paka ma Sabiti gi ndelo ma lamo man je
English: Drums call people to go to church for prayers on Sundays, and other prayer days

Adhola: Odoko wa goyo bunde ka wa wero i ka lamo Were aka wer bedo maloŋo
English: We also play drums to enrich songs when singing in churches

Adhola: Bul madwoŋ wero ni, “An a bul mba, an a bul mba, an a bul mbamba-mba-mba bul.”
English: The big drum sounds, "An a bul mba, an a bul mba, an a bul mbamba-mbamba bul."

Adhola: To nyithindhi bunde lirodwondi jo ma thindho ni, “Tindiri, tindiri tindiri ti.”
English: The small drums sing in their high pitches, "Tindiri, tindiri tindiri ti."

Adhola: Aka jo kworo kany'acel ni, “Tindiri mba, tindiri mba, tindiri mba-mbambamba, tindiri ti.”
English: Together they chorus, "Tindiri mba, tindiri mba, tindiri mba-mbambamba, tindiri ti!"

Adhola: Cango congo, oyido ogwange jo ngoye gi tyendi gin.
English: Long time ago, animals had no legs

Adhola: Maguru oyido omiyo ji kende tyendi jo
English: Only people had legs, which Maguru gave to them

Adhola: Maguru to bedo gi paro ma miyo kisi ogwaŋ tyende.
English: One day, Maguru decided to give legs to every animal

Adhola: Ogwange oyido jo mito tyendi jo ma woth kodi ma ŋwec
English: The animals wanted  legs so that they could walk and run

Adhola: Oyido tek ri jo kirweta arweta ka jo wotho.
English: They found it hard to crawl

Adhola: Munyo ndelo otundo, ogwange mupokere opokere jurweta kiri i ot pa Maguru
English: When the day came, many animals went to Maguru's house

Adhola: Maguru opoko ogwange kodi winyini tyendi jo
English: Each animal was given four legs

Adhola: Birds were given two legs each
English: Birds were given two legs each

Adhola: Ogwange megi jo myelo aka megi jo podho piny.
English: Some animals danced for joy and others fell down.

Adhola: To jo waco gi kisangala ni, "Wa kila kirweta doko ka wa wotho."
English: The animals said, "We will never crawl again."

Adhola: Ongongolo oyido obedo macowe i bol.
English: The last one in the line was Millipede

Adhola: Maguru omiyo Ongongolo tyendi mudoŋ jye
English: Maguru gave Millipede all the remaining legs

Adhola: Ongongolo okoko gi kisangala ni, "Ale wotho piyo piyo loyo ji je."
English: Millipede was very happy and  said, "I will move faster than others."

Adhola: Thwol otundo munyo ocow poko tyendi je
English: Snake arrived so that he can receive legs

Adhola: Oywakero ni womiy go tyendi moro
English: He pleaded to be  given me some legs

Adhola: Thwol owaco ri Maguru ni, "Agalo rupiri anindo tektek."
English: Snake said to Maguru, "I overslept."

Adhola: Maguru ku nyalo nwaŋo ri Thwol tyendi moro je
English: Maguru couldn't find some legs for Snake

Adhola: Woki ndelo no, Thwoli fodi kuro nwaŋo tyende
English: From that day, Snake is waiting  to get legs

Adhola: Lyec Gi Ŋokino
English: Elephant and Chameleon

Adhola: Cango, cango, cango i tindi moro obedo iye kere gi nyare maber swa
English: Once upon a time in a big palace, there lived a king and his beautiful daughter, the princess

Adhola: Oyido peco pa lyec nitye yuthenge acel ma tindi no
English: Elephant lived in a house on one side of the palace

Adhola: Aka okino oyido bende bedo yuthenge man
English: Chameleon lived on the other side

Adhola: I hongo no, ceŋ  olyel tektek swa i piny gi pi
English: At this time, there was a terrible drought across the land.

Adhola: To kere bedo gi paro to lwongo jo ger pere aryo me bino i tindi pere
English: The king had an idea and called his two neighbours to the palace

Adhola: Kere owaco ri Lyec gi Ŋokino ni, "Amito wi nyon piny gi tyendi win nyuka pi wok."
English: The king said to Elephant and Chameleon, “I want you to stomp on the ground with your feet until water comes out.”

Adhola: Kere ociko ni le miyo nyare ri ŋat meno ma onyal wodho pi
English: The king promised the princess in marriage to the one who succeeded

Adhola: Ŋokino ku bedo gi geno paka go oyido thin swa
English: Chameleon had no hope since he was very small

Adhola: Lyec osangala swa paka go oyido dwoŋ tektek aka nitye gi men
English: Elephant was extremely happy since he was so big and powerful

Adhola: Lyec okidho i ndelo to cako nyono piny
English: Elephant went to the field and started stomping on the ground

Adhola: Fukefuke mathoth oduny, to pi ku wok
English: A lot of dust came, but no water

Adhola: Lyec onyono anyona piny to ol
English: Elephant stomped on the ground but he was too tired.

Adhola: Pi oyido cegin wok!
English: Water was almost coming out

Adhola: To miyo Ŋokino silwany ni bende wo tem
English: He gave Chameleon a chance to try

Adhola: Ŋokino to cako nyono piny
English: Chameleon started stomping on the ground

Adhola: I hongo macek won, to pi wok
English: After a short while, water came out

Adhola: i jo kunyalo yeyo gi ma ju neno gi waŋ jo
English: People could not believe their eyes

Adhola: To kere miyo Ŋokino nyare maber
English: So the King gave the beautiful princess to Chameleon

Adhola: Omiyo Lyec wotho munyo kumo
English: That's why Elephant walks while angry

Adhola: Me Azizi
English: This is Azizi

Adhola: Azizi obedo dole paran
English: Azizi is my doll

Adhola: Amaro Azizi rupir go bwonjo i kisi sawa
English: I like Azizi because he always smiles

Adhola: Ka acew alwoko waŋan
English: After I wake up I wash my face

Adhola: To arango Azizi
English: Then I look for Azizi

Adhola: Ka anwaŋo Azizi agwaro rigo wiye
English: When I find Azizi I brush his hair

Adhola: Apidho Azizi bende ka acamo cemo m'odikin
English: When I eat breakfast I feed Azizi

Adhola: Ka acamo swit amiyo Azizi acel
English: When I eat sweets I give one to Azizi

Adhola: To Azizi ki cam swit pere
English: But Azizi never eats his sweet

Adhola: Akuya ni iraŋo!
English: I wonder why!

Adhola: Awotho thoko dyedipo ka adimo thiw yen
English: I walk around the compound picking flowers

Adhola: Amiyo Azizi thiw yen
English: I give a flower to Azizi

Adhola: Go kiwac kada ni, "Walwa!"
English: But he never says, “Thank you.”

Adhola: A lwoko Azizi m'olony ka fodi mama ku lwokan
English: I wash Azizi clean before my mother bathes me

Adhola: A ruko ri Aziz nanga m'obokere rupir amaro cal m'obokere
English: I dress Azizi in red because I love the colour red

Adhola: When I go to sleep, I lay Azizi beside me
English: Aketho Azizi dhu butan ka akidho nindo

Adhola: Anyalo idho!
English: I can climb!

Adhola: Ka nyathi mathini fwojere idho malo
English: Here, a little boy learns to climb up

Adhola: To go nyalo loro pinyi?
English: But can he climb down?

Adhola: Kitabo me obedo achieli kwongi kitabibi angweni i 'Dongo malo'.
English: This book is one of the four books in the 'Growing Up' series

Adhola: Abedo jiyachi madwongi same
English: I am a big boy now.

Adhola: Anyalo idho malo ma madala
English: I can climb up the steps.

Adhola: To akinyali loro pinyi doko
English: But I cannot climb down again

Adhola: Anyalo idho iwi komi
English: I can climb on a chair

Adhola: Anyalo idho iwi komi tamedere iwi meza!
English: I climb on to the chair, and then on the table!

Adhola: Akoko ni baba! baba!
English: I shout “Papa! Papa!”

Adhola: Baba nyero  towacho ni, 'Sonu fwonjere loro pinyi'.
English: Papa laughs and says  “Sonu, learn to climb down!”

Adhola: Anigi bwoki
English: I am afraid

Adhola: To aki ywaki.
English: But I do not cry

Adhola: Waŋ Ceŋ, Dwe, kodi Pi
English: Sun, Moon and Water

Adhola: Cango, cango, Ceŋ kodi Pi oyido jo mere
English: Many years ago, Sun and Water were great friends

Adhola: Oyido j'aryo je jo bedo i Piny ka kanyacel
English: Both lived on earth together

Adhola: Ceŋ oyido maro lyewo Pi radhik, to oyido Pi ki lyewi Ceŋ
English: Sun used to visit Water very often, but Water never went to visit Sun

Adhola: Rumacen Ceŋ openjo Pi gi ma miyo go ki lyewi ye jo
English: At last Sun asked Water why he never came to visit.

Adhola: Pi odwoko ni ot pa Ceŋ gin thin swa aka ka go obin gi wade pere nyalo ryemo woko Ceŋ
English: Water replied that Sun's house was too small and if he come with his family they will  drive Sun out

Adhola: To go waco ni, “Ka i yenyo ni alyewin, i ripo gero dye dipo ma lac
English: Then Water said, “If you wish me to visit you, build a very large compound

Adhola: Ji paran dit swa, aka jo tero ka bedo ma mathoth
English: My people are very many, and take up a lot of room

Adhola: Ceŋ ociko ni le geto dye dipo ma lac swa
English: Sun promised to build a very big compound

Adhola: Odok peco both dhako pere ma i lwoŋo ni Dwe
English: Sun returned home to his wife, Moon.

Adhola: Dwe ojolo go gi bwonjo m'oasere
English: Moon greeted him with a broad smile

Adhola: Ceŋ owaco ri Dwe gi ma go ociko Pi
English: Sun told Moon what he had promised Water

Adhola: Yawere mere ocako gero dye dipo ma lac swa ma le kuro iye mere pere
English: The next day he started building a huge compound in which to entertain his friend

Adhola: Munyo orumo, okwayo Pi bino lyewo jo yawere mere
English: As soon as the compound was completed, he asked Water to come and visit them

Adhola: Munyo Pi otundo, openjo Ceŋ ka inen ongoye gi ma cero go donjo
English: When Water arrived, he asked Sun whether it would be safe for him to enter

Adhola: Ceŋ odwoko ni, “Ongoye! donji mere paran.”
English: “Yes, come in, my friend,” Sun answered

Adhola: To Pi cako mol donjo i ot
English: Water began to flow in

Adhola: gi jo kwaŋ pere: ngona, rec, ogwale, thwondhe, othyololo, kacwe, ofuk, kanyacel gi ogwange je ma Pi.
English: He was accompanied by crocodiles, fish, frogs, snakes, snails, flukes, turtles, and all the water animals

Adhola: Pi opoŋ otundo i congi jo
English: Very soon Water was kneedeep

Adhola: Openjo Ceŋ ka ineni fodi jo nyalo medere donjo to Ceŋ odoko yeyo
English: He asked Sun if it was still safe

Adhola: Ri ameno Pi omedere donjo
English: “Yes,” Sun again answered. So more of water's people came in

Adhola: Pi otundo mwonyo wic dhano
English: Water reached the level of the top of a person's head

Adhola: To go penjo ceŋ ni, “Fodi imito ji paran man jo wo donji?”
English: He asked Sun, “Can more of my people come in?”

Adhola: Ceŋ gi Dwe je to jo yeyo
English: Sun and Moon both agreed

Adhola: Ameno Pi omol amola tundo kuma Ceŋ gi Dwe jo ayi to jothundhere malo wi kisul
English: Water flowed on, until Sun and Moon had to perch themselves on the top of the roof

Adhola: Ji pa Pi jo mula mula i ot
English: Water's people continued to rush in

Adhola: Ma Piyo Piyo Pi otundo i kisul ot
English: Very soon they reached the top of the roof

Adhola: Ceŋ gi Dwe to jo idhere to jo kadho de i polo kama
English: Sun and Moon were forced to go up into the sky

Adhola: jo doŋ iye wok ndir no
English: They have remained in the sky ever since

Adhola: KUDINI KORONA
English: CORONAVIRUS

Adhola: N'geri ma pokere iye?
English: How is it spread?

Adhola: Inyalo nwang'o kudini ma Korona ka I geyo giro pa n'gata tuwo kosa lawi mawuto kama othoni iye.
English: You can get infected with Coronavirus if you get in contact with an infected person's sneeze or cough droplets

Adhola: Kudini ma Korona rach swa aka nyayi tekiteki doko nyalo kelo tho
English: Coronavirus is dangerous, spreads fast and can lead to death

Adhola: Inyalo geng'o nwa'ngo tuwo Korona luwo kwo'ngi giratima me:
English: You can prevent getting infected with Corona by observing the following:

Adhola: Gwokere kwo'ngi dhano manitiye kodi ranyuthi ma wolo gi modhino umijo.
English: Avoiding contact with anyone  with a cold or flu-like symptoms

Adhola: Umi dhokini kodi umini ka iwolo kodi giro iyi bon'gi mulonyi
English: Covering the nose and mouth when sneezing and coughing with a tissue or flexed elbow

Adhola: Ketho kineni malwoko chi'ngini gi pi kodi sabuni.
English: Regularly washing your hands  with water and soap

Adhola: Tecli rin'go maberi kodi to'ngi kweno mucheki ma beri kichutho
English: Thoroughly cooking meat and  eggs

Adhola: lkiri bende imulo ogwange madudi kanyacheli kodi apidha pecho miki ruko ragwoki ikwo per'
English: Avoiding unprotected contact with live wild or farm animals

Adhola: N'geyo mathoth, twongi Kwethi ma mako kwo'ngi kwo isimo:
English: For more information, call the Ministry of Health toll free line on:

Adhola: Ranyuthi gi ranena ma tuwo kudini Korona?
English: Signs and symptoms

Adhola: Modhino umijo
English: Fever

Adhola: Wolo
English: Cough

Adhola: Adhola idwondi jo
English: Sore throat

Adhola: Peko iyuwe
English: Shortness of breath

Adhola: wanitye nokinoki iniang i timo tich mawan
English: We’re just a few formalities away from getting down to work.

Adhola: Jume teri ye sawa perin i neni gima wamiyo
English: Please take the time to review our offer.

Adhola: Nitye iye thenethene maberi ma mako kwongi michi, bero kodi chicki ma ini nwango tich kodi Agoya Limited
English: It includes important details about your compensation, benefits and the terms and conditions of your anticipated employment with Ogayo Limited.

Adhola: Ogoya Limited miyo (sawa jye, adech sawa, kodi megi jye...)kabedo ma tic rini paka(Nyingi tich),
English: Ogayo Limited is offering a [full time, part time, etc] position for you as [job title], reporting to [immediate manager/supervisor] starting on [proposed start date] at [workplace location].

Adhola: sawa ma mitere ma tic obedo [ndelo ma sabiti kodi saw ma tich].
English: Expected hours of work are [days of week and hours of work].

Adhola: I kifwo me, Agayo Limited omiyo chako chulo pesa dollars kosa misara ma sawa kosa oro gi pi.
English: In this position, Ogayo Limited is offering to start you at a pay rate of dollar amount or annual base salary per year, hour, annual salary, etc.

Adhola: I lachulin ma sabiti, i dwe, kodi megi..ma lackakere I hongo macul ma bino
English: You will be paid on a weekly, monthly, etc basis, starting date of next pay period.

Adhola: Paka ja tic mapa Ogayo Limited I la nwango thieli ma kitinda kwo perin
English: As an employee of Ogayo Limited you will be eligible for health insurance.

Adhola: Jume kethi ranuthi manyutho ni i soma aka iyere gi tich ma wamiyini ka i ketho chingini kodi ndelo ma dwe ma yeyirok me kora mafoudi chwe ma tich me korumo
English: Please indicate your agreement with these terms and accept this offer by signing and dating this agreement on or before offer expiration date.

Adhola: Me a bol ma nywolirok pa Yesu Kristo, nyakwar Daudi, nyakwar Ibrayimu
English: A record of the genealogy of Jesus Christ the son of David, the son of Abraham

Adhola: Ibrayimu onywolo Isaka, Isaka to nywolo Yakobo, Yakobo to nywolo Yuda gi wutumin go;
English: Abraham was the father of Isaac, and Isaac the father of Jacob, and Jacob the father of Judah and his brothers

Adhola: Yakobo to nywolo Yozefu, mobedo chwor Marya, monywolo Yesu milwoŋo ni Kristo.
English: Jacob fathered Joseph the husband of Mary, of whom Jesus was born, who is called Christ.

Adhola: Ri ameno, wok kwoŋ Ibrayimu tundo kwoŋi Daudi, obedo luse ji apar g'aŋwen; odoko wok kwoŋ Daudi, tundo munyo oter jo yu Babilon, obedo luse ji apar gaŋwen; kendo wok munyo oter jo yu Babilon tundo kwoŋ Kristo, bende obedo luse ji apar g'aŋwen.
English: So all the generations from Abraham to David were fourteen generations, and from David to the deportation to Babylon fourteen generations, and from the deportation to Babylon to the Christ fourteen generations.

Adhola: Nywolirok pa Yesu Kristo
English: The birth of Jesus

Adhola: Me apaka nywolirok pa Yesu Kristo obedo: Munyo Yozefu fuodi oido nyaka jochikere nywomirok kodi Marya min Yesu, ma fuodi korwako go i ot, to nenere ni go oido otyeko gamo iye i men pa Chuny Maleŋ.
English: Now the birth of Jesus Christ took place in this way. When his mother Mary had been betrothed to Joseph, before they came together she was found to be with child from the Holy Spirit.

Adhola: Gikenyo Yozefu chwore, rupiri oido obedo dhano motire aka komito miyo go wichkwot, oido paro weyo go nyaliŋliŋ.
English: And her husband Joseph, being a just man and unwilling to put her to shame, resolved to divorce her quietly.

Adhola: Neni, munyo fuodi go paro ameno, malaika pa Ruoth to bino ri go i lek, to wacho ri go ni, “Yozefu wuodi pa Daudi, ikiri ilwor rwako Marya bedo dhako perin, rupiri go yach gi men pa Chuny Maleŋ.
English: But as he considered these things, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream, saying, “Joseph, son of David, do not fear to take Mary as your wife, for that which is conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit.

Adhola: Go bino nywolo nyathi ma jayach, aka ibino chwoko nyinge ni Yesu; rupiri go ama bino botho ji pere kwoŋ recho pajo.”
English: She will bear a son, and you shall call his name Jesus, for he will save his people from their sins.”

Adhola: Gino jye otimere, ŋey gima jatuchi wach Were oluwo wotundi i kare
English: All this took place to fulfill what the Lord had spoken by the prophet

Adhola: Nyako ma fuodi kuya jachwo bino gamo iye, to nywolo nyathi ma jayach, ma ibino chwoko nyinge ni “Emanwel”,dwoŋ mere ni, “Were ni gi wan.”
English: Behold, the virgin shall conceive and bear a son, and they shall call his name “Immanuel” which means, “ God with us.”

Adhola: Yozefu munyo ochiew, to timo paka malaika pa Were owacho ri go, to tero Marya bedo chiege.
English: When Joseph woke from sleep, he did as the angel of the Lord commanded him: he took his wife.

Adhola: aka koŋeyere gine tundo munyo ochowo nywolo nyathi no
English: but knew her not until she had given birth to a son

Adhola: to chwoko nyinge ni Yesu.
English: And he called his name Jesus.

Adhola: Munyo otyek nywolo Yesu i tindi ma Bethlehem, i Yudeya i ndir ma Herode oido kere, joryeko mogo ma jofuonjere kwoŋ michalin jowok yu Wokchieŋ to jobino Yerusalem aka jopenjo ni, “Nikune nyathi monywol bedo kere pa Joyudaya?"
English: After Jesus was born in Bethlehem in Judea, during the time of King Herod, Magi from the east came to Jerusalemand asked, “Where is the one who has been born king of the Jews? ”

Adhola: Waneno michala pere munyo owok yu Wokchieŋ amomiyo onyo wabino lamo go.
English: We saw his star in the east and have come to worship him.

Adhola: Munyo Kere Herode owinjo gime, obwok, aka kir gi ji man jye i Yerusalem.
English: When King Herod heard this he was disturbed, and all Jerusalem with him

Adhola: Go olwoŋo jotel pa jochwayi ri Were wi alitar jye kodi jofuonji ma Chik kanyachiel to penjo jo ni, “Ibino nywolo Kristo kune?”
English: When he had called together all the people's chief priests and teachers of the law, he asked them where the Christ was to be born

Adhola: Jodwoko ni, “I tindi ma Bethlehem, i Yudeya, me a gima jatuchi wach Were ondiko ”
English: They replied, “In Bethlehem in Judea, for this is what the prophet has written"

Adhola:
In Bethlehem, i piny pa Yuda,
iŋati ikiasa thin i dyer jodhum ma Yuda;
kole kwoŋin ama jatel bino wok'iye,
ma bino bedo jakwath pa Joisrael.
English: “ ‘And you, O Bethlehem, in the land of Judah, are by no means least among the rulers of Judah; for from you shall come a ruler who will shepherd my people Israel.’ ”

Adhola: Gikenyo Herode olwoŋo wendo ma jowok yu Wokchieŋ no i romo ma nyaliŋliŋ, aka oŋeyo kwoŋ jo ndir won ma michala no omenyer'iye ri jo.
English: Then Herod summoned the wise men secretly and ascertained from them what time the star had appeared. 8

Adhola: Gikenyo ooro jo Bethlehem gi wach me: “Kidhi win wirangi kama di nyathi no maber aka ka winwaŋo go wimiyan ŋeyo, ŋey abende abin alam go.”
English: And he sent them to Bethlehem, saying, “Go and search diligently for the child, and when you have found him, bring me word, that I too may come and worship him.”

Adhola: Gi wach me joeye kenyo, aka munyo oido jowotho i royo, joneno michala ma ndir cha joneno yu Wokchieŋ, motelo jo chuka otundo to chungo kama nyathi no oido ni iye.
English: When they had heard the king, they departed; and, lo, the star, which they saw in the east, went before them, till it came and stood over where the young child was.

Adhola: Josangala swa, kendo jowinjo maber moasere munyo joneno michala no!
English: When they saw the star, they rejoiced with exceeding great joy.

Adhola: Jodonjo i ot to joneno nyathi bongi Marya yokimere.
English: And going into the house they saw the child with Mary his mother, and they fell down and worshiped him.

Adhola: Joguro chongi gin piny jolamo go, to joyawo migowe pajo, to jochwayo mich: zawabu, buban, kodi mo maŋwe kur.
English: Then, opening their treasures, they offered him gifts, gold and frankincense and myrrh.

Adhola: Were onyutho jo i lek nike jokiri jogiki kendo pa Herode, ri ameno jodok yu piny pajo gi royo man.
English: And being warned in a dream not to return to Herod, they departed to their own country by another way.

Adhola: Munyo jotyeko kadho, malaika pa Ruoth omenyere ri Yozefu i lek munyo wacho ni, “Ayi malo ikwanyi nyathi gi yokimere wiringi i piny Misir, aka wibedi koro nyuka anowachi ri win ndir ma dwoko. Herode lerango nyathi no munyo mito neko.”
English: Now when they had departed, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared to Joseph in a dream and said, “Rise, take the child and his mother, and flee to Egypt, and remain there until I tell you, for Herod is about to search for the child, to destroy him.”

Adhola: Amomiyo Yozefu oay malo okwanyo nyathi gi yokimere, to joay wor kidho yu Misir; kama go obed'iye chuka Herode otho.
English: And he rose and took the child and his mother by night and departed to Egypt and remained there until the death of Herod.

Adhola: Meno omiyo gima jatuchi wach Were owacho chon otundo i kare ni, “Alwoŋo wuodan wok Misir.”
English: This was to fulfill what the Lord had spoken by the prophet, “Out of Egypt I called my son.”

Adhola: Neko nyithindho maŋich
English: The Slaying of the Infants

Adhola: Ringo i piny Misir
English: The flight to Egypt

Adhola: Munyo Herode oneno ni joryeko ma jowok yu Wokchieŋ jothumo ri go ryeko, keme omako go to wodho or nike woneki woko nyithindho mayach jye ma joromo oro aryo gik chien, i Bethlehem kodi loka mothenere gine.
English: Then Herod, when he saw that he had been tricked by the wise men, became furious, and he sent and killed all the male children in Bethlehem and in all that region who were two years old or under.

Adhola: kwoŋ ndir ma go openj'iye joryeko cha kwoŋ menyirok pa michala.
English: according to the time that he had ascertained from the wise men.

Adhola: Ameno gima Yeremiya jatuchi wach Were owacho otundo i kare
English: Then was fulfilled what was spoken by the prophet Jeremiah:

Adhola: Derino winjere yu Rama, derino ma ywak malith gi ndur.
English: A voice was heard in Ramah, weeping and loud lamentation,

Adhola: Rakel ywako nyithindho pere.
English: Rachel weeping for her children.

Adhola: Kiyey wokwey chunye, rupiri ongoye modoŋ.
English: She refused to be comforted, because they are no more.

Adhola: Dwoko wok Misir
English: The return from Egypt

Adhola: Munyo Herode otyeko tho, malaika pa Ruoth omenyere ri Yozefu i lek yu Misir.
English: But when Herod died, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared in a dream to Joseph in Egypt.

Adhola: Aka owacho ni, “Ayi malo ikwanyi nyathi gi yokimere widoki i piny Israel rupiri joma oido jorango neko go jotyeko tho.”
English: Then he said, “Rise, take the child and his mother and go to the land of Israel, for those who sought the child’s life are dead.”

Adhola: Amomiyo Jozefu oay malo, okwanyo nyathi gi yokimere to jodok yu piny Israel.
English: And he rose and took the child and his mother and went to the land of Israel.

Adhola: Munyo Yozefu owinjo ni Akelayus ama olunjo kom pa bamere Herode paka kere ma Yudeya, lworo omako go dok kendo kenyo.
English: But when he heard that Archelaus was reigning over Judea in place of his father Herod, he was afraid to go there

Adhola: Were omedo menyo rigo i lek, amomiyo go okidho i adech ma Galileya
English: And being warned in a dream he withdrew to the district of Galilee.

Adhola: To gero pecho pere i tindi ma Nazareth.
English: And he went and lived in a city called Nazareth

Adhola: Go otimo ameno ma miyo gima jatuchi wach Were owacho wotundi ni, “Ibino lwoŋo go ni Janazareth.”
English: He did that so  that it might be fulfilled what was spoken by the prophets: “He shall be called a Nazarene.”

Adhola: Fuonji pa Yohana Jakibatisa
English: The teachings of John the Baptist

Adhola: I hongo no Yohana Jakibatisa obino to chako tito wach Were i thim ma Yudeya
English: In those days John the Baptist came preaching in the wilderness of Judea

Adhola: Ŋuti win, rupiri Ker ma polo ni chiegin!
English: Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.

Adhola: Yohana oido a ŋata Isaya jatuchi wach Were chango oluwo kwoŋe chon
English: For this is he who was spoken of by the prophet Isaiah

Adhola: Nyatoro koko i thim ni:
English: The voice of one crying in the wilderness

Adhola: Yiki win royo pa Ruoth, tiri win rigo royo pere.
English: Prepare the way of the Lord; make his paths straight.

Adhola: Ruuk pa Yohana oido otim ma yer ŋamira, aka go oido tweyo pyere gi del ma pyen, aka chiemo pere oido obedo bonyo kodi mo kich.
English: Now John wore a garment of camel’s hair and a leather belt around his waist, and his food was locusts and wild honey.

Adhola: Ji jobino bonge wok Yerusalem, wok i adech ma Yudeya, kodi wok i adeche jye mothoko jwom Yordan.
English: Then Jerusalem and all Judea and all the region about the Jordan were going out to him,

Adhola: Jotucho gimarecho pajo aka omiy jo batisimo i Yordan.
English: They confessed their sins and were baptized by him in the Jordan.

Adhola: Munyo Yohana oneno kweth Jofarisayo kodi Josadukayo jobino bonge limo batisimo, owacho ri jo ni, “Win nyithindhi thwole, ŋata onyutho win ryeko ma both kwoŋ keme pa Were ma chiegin bino?
English: But when he saw many of the Pharisees and Sadducees coming to his baptism, he said to them, “You brood of vipers! Who warned you to flee from the wrath to come?"

Adhola: Timi win gima nyutho nike wityeko ŋuto gimarecho mewin kichutho.
English: Bear fruit in keeping with repentance.

Adhola: Aka wikiri wipar ni winyalo nwaŋo kagoŋirok munyo wiwacho ni, ‘Ibrayimu obedo kwari wan.’
English: And do not presume to say to yourselves, ‘We have Abraham as our father.’

Adhola: Awacho ri win ni Were nyalo kwanyo kada telin me to loko nyikway Ibrayimu!
English: For I tell you, God is able from these stones to raise up children for Abraham.

Adhola: Kada pama le otyek yiko ma toŋo yen gi i tyendi gin!
English: Even now the axe is laid to the root of the trees.

Adhola: Yath jye ma kinyak gimaber ibino toŋo woko tibolo i mach!
English: Every tree therefore that does not bear good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire.

Adhola: Amiyo win batisimo kodi pi ma nyutho nike wityeko ŋuto; to ŋata bino luwan chien bino miyo win batisimo gi Chuny Maleŋ kodi mach.
English: I baptize you with water for repentance, but he who is coming after me will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and fire.

Adhola: Go loyan gi dwoŋ tektek ma akiripi kada tiŋo war pere.
English: He is mightier than I that I am not worthy to carry his sandals.

Adhola: Go nitye g'odher pere ma yeko nyingi kal jye; go bino choko kal pere malilo to konjo i dero pere, to waŋo woko chuŋ i mach makitho.
English: His winnowing fork is in his hand, and he will clear his threshing floor and gather his wheat into the barn, but the chaff he will burn with unquenchable fire.

Adhola: Batisimo pa Yesu
English: The baptism of Jesus

Adhola: I hongo no Yesu owok Galileya to kidho Yordan to bino bongi Yohana ni womiy go batisimo.
English: Then Jesus came from Galilee to the Jordan to John, to be baptized by him.

Adhola: To Yohana otemo juko go ka wacho ri go ni, “Aŋata oido aripo limo batisimo bongin, odoko ibino bongan ayino!”
English: John would have prevented him, saying, “I need to be baptized by you, and do you come to me?”

Adhola: To Yesu odwoko go ni, “Weyi watim ameno pama. Kole i tim me wabino tiro gimoro jye ma Were yenyo.”
English: But Jesus answered him, “Let it be so now, for thus it is fitting for us to fulfill all righteousness.”

Adhola: To Yohana yeyo.
English: Then he consented.

Adhola: Tekin Yesu chowo limo batisimo, owok i pi.
English: And when Jesus was baptized, immediately he went up from the water

Adhola: Gikenyo polo oyawere ri go aka oneno Chuny Maleŋ loro piny i chal pa akuru to pye kwoŋe.
English: And behold, the heavens were opened to him, and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove and coming to rest on him

Adhola: Gikenyo dwondi nyatoro oluwo wok i polo ni, “Me a Wuodan won mamaro, aka asangala gine.”
English: And behold, a voice from heaven said, “This is my beloved Son, with whom I am well pleased.”

Adhola: Jwogi temo Yesu
English: The devil tempts Jesus

Adhola: Gikenyo Chuny Maleŋ otero Yesu i thim ŋey jwogi wotem go.
English: Then Jesus was led up by the Spirit into the wilderness to be tempted by the devil.

Adhola: Munyo go ochowo odyechieŋ gi wor pyero aŋwen munyo riyo, Yesu owinjo kech.
English: And after fasting forty days and forty nights, he was hungry.

Adhola: Jwogi obino bonge to wacho ni, “K'inen ibedo Wuodi Were adyeri, ere apawiri telin me wolokere chiemo.”
English: And the tempter came and said to him, “If you are the Son of God, command these stones to become loaves of bread.”

Adhola: Yesu odwoko ni, “Ondik ni, ‘Dhano kinyal kwo gi chiemo kende, to gi wach jye mawok i dhoki Were.’ ”
English: Jesus answered, “It is written, “ ‘Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that comes from the mouth of God.’ ”

Adhola: Gikenyo jwogi otero Yesu i tindi maleŋ to ketho go wi kisul ma Ot pa Were,
English: Then the devil took him to the holy city and set him on the pinnacle of the temple

Adhola: o wacho ri go ni, “K'inen ibedo Wuodi Were ere paporiye piny"
English: And said to him, “If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down"

Adhola: Were bino oro rin jomalaika pere,ma jobino byelin i chingi gin,aka ikibino chadho tyendin kwoŋ tele.
English: He will command his angels concerning you and On their hands they will bear you up, lest you strike your foot against a stone.

Adhola: Yesu odwoko ni, “Kole ondik bende ni, ‘Ikiri item Ruoth Were perin.’ ”
English: Jesus replied, “Again it is written, ‘You shall not put the Lord your God to the test.’ ”

Adhola: Gikenyo jwogi otero Yesu wi got mabor swa, to nyutho go ker ma piny jye, gi dwoŋ mani iye jye.
English: Again, the devil took him to a very high mountain and showed him all the kingdoms of the world and their glory.

Adhola: Jwogi owacho ni, “Abino miyin gigo jye, ka iryewere ruwaŋan t'ilaman.”
English: The devil said, “All these I will give you, if you will fall down and worship me.”

Adhola: Gikenyo Yesu odwoko ni, “Eye bongan Sitan! Ondik ni, ‘Lami Ruoth Were perin aka itiy ri go won kende.’ ”
English: Then Jesus said to him, “Be gone, Satan! For it is written, “ ‘You shall worship the Lord your God and him only shall you serve.’ ”

Adhola: Gikenyo jwogi oweyo go; aka jomalaika jobino jomiyo go kony.
English: Then the devil left him, and behold, angels came and were ministering to him.

Adhola: Munyo Yesu owinjo ni otwey Yohana, go oay to kidho Galileya.
English: Now when he heard that John had been arrested, he withdrew into Galilee.

Adhola: Go oeye Nazareth, to kidho Kapernaum, tindi ma dho jwom Galileya, i adech mapa Zebulun kodi Naftal.
English: And leaving Nazareth he went and lived in Capernaum by the sea, in the territory of Zebulun and Naphtali,.

Adhola: Gime otimere ma miyo gima Isaya jatuchi wach Were owacho wotundi i kare
English: 14 so that what was spoken by the prophet Isaiah might be fulfilled

Adhola: Piny pa Zebulun, piny pa Naftal,thenge ma yu wakawaka, i thengi Yordan, Galileya, pa Jopath!
English: The land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, the way of the sea, beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles

Adhola: Ji moido jonitye i mudho joneno lero madwoŋ aka ri joma oido jonitye i piny ma mudho ma tho, lero otyeko menyere.”
English: The people dwelling in darkness have seen a great light, and for those dwelling in the region and shadow of death, on them a light has dawned.

Adhola: Wok i hongo no kadho yuwaŋe Yesu ochako fuonjo ka wacho ni, “Ŋuti win recho rupiri Ker ma polo ni chiegin.”
English: From that time Jesus began to preach, saying, “Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.”

Adhola: Yesu lwoŋo chwo aŋwen ma jokitoga
English: Jesus calls four fishermen

Adhola: Munyo Yesu oido wotho dho Wakawaka Galileya, go oneno wutimere aryo ma jokitoga, Simon (milwoŋo ni Petro) kodi Andereya omin go, munyo oido jochiko rech i wakawaka gi bwoo rupiri oido jobedo jokitoga.
English: While walking by the Sea of Galilee, he saw two brothers, Simon (who is called Peter) and Andrew his brother, casting a net into the sea, for they were fishermen.

Adhola: Yesu owacho ri jo ni, “Biye luwan win aloki win jokitoga ji.”
English: And he said to them, “Follow me, and I will make you fishers of men.”

Adhola: Piyo piyo jono joweyo bwoo pajo, to joluwo go.
English: Immediately they left their nets and followed him.

Adhola: Yesu omedere woth aka oneno wutimere aryo man, Yakobo kodi Yohana, yach pa Zebedayo.
English: Jesus continued walking from there he saw two other brothers, James the son of Zebedee and John his brother

Adhola: Onwaŋo jonitye i yee pajo gi baa gin Zebedayo joyiko bwoo pajo, to lwoŋo jo.
English: He found them in the boat with Zebedee their father, mending their nets, and he called them.

Adhola: Piyo piyo jono joweyo yee pajo gi baa gin, to joluwo Yesu.
English: Immediately they left the boat and their father and followed him.

Adhola: Yesu tito wach gi botho ji
English: Jesus ministers the word to people

Adhola: Yesu owotho i Galileya parom, munyo fuonjo Wach Maber kwoŋ Ker pa Were i kalamo pa Joyudaya, gi botho two kodi ramirok ma nger jye.
English: Jesus went throughout all Galilee, teaching in their synagogues and proclaiming the gospel of the kingdom and healing every disease and every affliction among the people.

Adhola: Wach ma mako kwoge onyay i piny Sirya gipi, momiyo ji jokelo ri go ji jye monwaŋo jotwo kiti two mopokere jye, kodi ramirok ma nger jye moido chando jo: ji ma jwogi ni kwoŋ gin, joma tho fum, kodi jonyaŋinya; to Yesu botho jo jye.
English: So his fame spread throughout all Syria, and they brought him all the sick, those afflicted with various diseases and pains, those oppressed by demons, epileptics, and paralytics, and he healed them.

Adhola: Kweth ji moasere joluwo go wok Galileya kodi Dekapoli  wok Yerusalem, Yudeya, kodi piny ma loka Yordan.
English: And great crowds followed him from Galilee and the Decapolis, and from Jerusalem and Judea, and from beyond the Jordan.

Adhola: tindi mochokere apar
English: A group of ten cities

Adhola: Fuonji wi got
English: The sermon on the mount

Adhola: Yesu oneno kitipa ji, to idho wi got, aka munyo otyeko bedo piny, jofuonjirok pere jobino bothe
English: Seeing the crowds, he went up on the mountain, and when he sat down, his disciples came to him.

Adhola: Aka ochako fuonjo jo ni:
English: And he started teaching

Adhola: “Josilwany a joma chandere i chuny gin, rupiri Ker ma polo obedo apa jo.
English: Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

Adhola: Josilwany a joma ywak,rupiri ibino kweyo chuny jo.
English: Blessed are those who mourn, for they shall be comforted.

Adhola: Josilwany a joma mwol, rupiri jobino lunjo piny.
English: Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth.

Adhola: Josilwany a joma nitye g'awanya madwoŋ ma timo gima Were yenyo, rupiri ibino yeŋo jo.
English: Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they shall be satisfied.

Adhola: Josilwany a joma nyutho jowoti gin wor, rupiri Were bino nyutho jo bende wor.
English: Blessed are the merciful, for they shall receive mercy.

Adhola: Josilwany a joma chuny gin olony, rupiri jobino neno Were.
English: Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God.

Adhola: Josilwany joma kweyo piny, rupiri ibino lwoŋo jo ni nyithindho pa Were.
English: Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called sons of God.

Adhola: Josilwany a joma ilwenyo gi jo ru timo gima Were yenyo, rupiri Ker ma polo obedo apa jo!
English: Blessed are those who are persecuted for righteousness’ sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

Adhola: Win wi josilwany ka ji joyeto win aka jolwenyo gi win, ka jowacho wach jye kwoŋ win rupiri wibedo joma luwan.
English: Blessed are you when others revile you and persecute you and utter all kinds of evil against you falsely on my account.

Adhola: Yodere win aka wisangala, rupiri kemba mewin obedo moasere i polo.
English: Rejoice and be glad, for your reward is great in heaven.

Adhola: Me apaka chango jotimo kir ri jotuchi wach Were machon.
English: This is how they persecuted the prophets who were before you.

Adhola: Chumbi kodi lero
English: Salt and light

Adhola: Wibedo kado chumbi ma piny.
English: You are the salt of the earth.

Adhola: To ka kado chumbi orwenyo woko chwe mere, aŋo ma nyalo miyo go bedo mamit kendo?
English: But if salt has lost its taste, how shall its saltiness be restored?

Adhola: Lokere gima ongoye kony; amomiyo ikonjo woko to ji nyono gi tyendi gin.
English: It is no longer good for anything except to be thrown out and trampled under people’s feet.

Adhola: Win wiŋati wibedo lero ma piny.
English: You are the light of the world.

Adhola: Tindi moger wi tendere madwoŋ kipanere.
English: A city set on a hill cannot be hidden.

Adhola: Ongoye ŋata chwinyo tala to ryewo i agono; kuchiel go ripo ŋawo tala no malo kuma nyalo miyo lero ri ji jye ma ot.
English: Nor do people light a lamp and put it under a basket, but on a stand, and it gives light to all in the house.

Adhola: Ri ameno lero mewin bende ripo menyo iye jye ŋey ji jowoneni gima beyo ma witimo to jopako Baa win mani polo.
English: In the same way, let your light shine before others, so that they may see your good works and give glory to your Father who is in heaven.

Adhola: Fuonji kwoŋ Chik
English: Teaching on the law

Adhola: Wikiri wipar nike abino ka kwanyo woko Chik pa Musa kodi fuonji pa jotuchi wach Were, to abino nyutho dwoŋ mere maradyeri ayin.
English: Do not think that I have come to abolish the Law or the Prophets; I have not come to abolish them but to fulfill them.

Adhola: Adyeri awacho ri win, ka polo gi piny fuodi nitye, ongoye kada gimathin kosa adech mondhilo kwoŋ Chik mibino kwanyo woko, to bino bedo ama tundo kama gimoro jye otyeko timer'iye.
English: For truly, I say to you, until heaven and earth pass away, not an iota, not a dot, will pass from the Law until all is accomplished.

Adhola: Amomiyo nyatoro jye mokweri winjo kada gimoro nyaka mathin kwoŋ Chik aka ofuonji joman bende timo ameno, bino bedo ŋata loyo thino i Ker ma polo.
English: Therefore whoever relaxes one of the least of these commandments and teaches others to do the same will be called least in the kingdom of heaven.

Adhola: Kuchiel nyatoro jye mowinji Chik aka ofuonji joman bende timo ameno, bino bedo ŋata dwoŋ swa i Ker ma polo.
English: But whoever does them and teaches them will be called great in the kingdom of heaven.

Adhola: Amomiyo, awacho ri win ni wikibino nyalo donjo i Ker ma polo kwanyo woko ka wibedo gi leŋo ma kalo apa jofuonji ma Chik kodi Jofarisayo i timo gima Were yenyo.
English: For I tell you, unless your righteousness exceeds that of the scribes and Pharisees, you will never enter the kingdom of heaven.

Adhola: Fuonji kwoŋ nge
English: Teaching on murder

Adhola: Wityeko winjo ni chango owach ri ji machon ni, ‘Ikiri ineki, aka nyatoro jye ma janek ibino tero go ruwaŋ jathum banja.’
English: “You have heard that it was said to those of old, ‘You shall not murder; and whoever murders will be liable to judgment.’

Adhola: To pama onyo awacho ri win ama: ŋata omaki nge g'omin bino bedo gi banja kapido.
English: But I say to you that everyone who is angry with his brother will be liable to judgment.

Adhola: Ŋata otim rooro kwoŋ omin ibino tero go ruwaŋ jothumi banja, aka ŋata oyeti omin ni, ‘Mamiŋ ma bu kony,’ ibino bolo go i mach makitho.
English: Whoever insults his brother will be liable to the council; and whoever says, ‘You fool!’will be liable to the hell of fire.

Adhola: Amomiyo ka onwaŋo itero mich perin ri Were wi alitar to gikenyo ipoyo nike omerin nitye gi dhaw kodin,  weyi mich perin i nyim alitar kenyo,
English: So if you are offering your gift at the altar and there remember that your brother has something against you, leave your gift there before the altar and go.

Adhola: kutho ikidhi iyiki wach g'omerin aka nyaka idwoki imiyi Were mich perin.
English: First be reconciled to your brother, and then come and offer your gift to God

Adhola: Ka dhano ni gi wach moro kodin aka mito terin kapido, yiki gine wach no ma fuodi hongo nitye, ka fuodi wikitundo kapido.
English: Come to terms quickly with your accuser while you are going with him to court

Adhola: Ka winotundi kenyo, go bino bolin i chingi jathumi banja, ma bino kethin i chingi joserikale ma katwech titweyin.
English: When you arrive there, she will hand you over to the judge, and the judge to the guard, and you be put in prison.

Adhola: Ibino bedo kenyo, awacho rin, nyuka inochul kir pesa machowe mothumi rin.
English: I say to you, you will never get out until you have paid the last penny.

Adhola: Fuonji kwoŋ turo chik ma nywomirok
English: Teaching on breaking the law of marriage

Adhola: Wityeko winjo paka chango owach ni, ‘Ikiri itim chot.
English: “You have heard that it was said, ‘You shall not commit adultery.’

Adhola: To pama awacho ri win ama: ŋata ŋiyo dhako moro aka chunye wanya go, meno otyeko timo gine chot gi i chunye.
English: But I say to you that everyone who looks at a woman with lustful intent has already committed adultery with her in his heart.

Adhola: Amomiyo k'inen waŋin marachuch miyin timo gimarach, goli woko iboli woko!
English: If your right eye causes you to sin, tear it out and throw it away.

Adhola: Kole ber ikeŋi adech moro ma delkwoŋin loyo nwaŋo delkwoŋin gipi tibolo i mach makitho.
English: For it is better that you lose one of your members than that your whole body be thrown into hell.

Adhola: K'inen chingin marachuch miyin timo gimarach, ŋondi ibol woko!
English: And if your right hand causes you to sin, cut it off and throw it away.

Adhola: Rupiri ber iremi chingin achiel loyo delkwoŋin gipi kidho i mach makitho.
English: For it is better that you lose one of your members than that your whole body go into hell.

Adhola: Fuonji kwoŋ ryemo dhako
English: Teaching on divorcing your wife

Adhola: Chango chon owach ni, ‘Nyatoro ma ryemo woko chiege ripo miyo go balwa ma ryemo go i ndiiko.’
English: It was also said, ‘Whoever divorces his wife, let him give her a certificate of divorce.’

Adhola: To pama awacho ri win ni: nyatoro jye moryemi chiege ri wach moro jye ma kobedo wach ma kidakana, meno go miyo chiege donjo i chot.
English: But I say to you that everyone who divorces his wife, except on the ground of sexual immorality, makes her commit adultery.

Adhola: Aka ŋata nywomo dhako ma pameno, meno bende timo gine chot.
English: And whoever marries a divorced woman commits adultery.

Adhola: Fuonji kwoŋ kwoŋirok
English: Teaching on swearing

Adhola: Wityeko winjo paka chango chon owach ni, ‘Ikiri ikwoŋere ma twodo, to timi gima ikwoŋere timo i nyim Ruoth.’
English: Again you have heard that it was said to those of old, ‘You shall not swear falsely, but shall perform to the Lord what you have sworn.’

Adhola: To pama awacho ri win ni: ikiri ikwoŋere kada mathin ka itimo chikirok, ikiri ikwoŋere gi polo, rupiri meno kom pa Were,  kosa gi piny, rupiri meno kaywomo tyende, kosa gi Yerusalem, rupiri meno obedo tindi pa Kere madwoŋ.
English: But I say to you, Do not take an oath at all, either by heaven, for it is the throne of God, or by the earth, for it is his footstool, or by Jerusalem, for it is the city of the great King.

Adhola: Odoko ikiri ikwoŋere gi wiyin, rupiri ikinyal loko kada yer achiel matar wobedi machol kosa machol wobedi matar.
English: And do not take an oath by your head, for you cannot make one hair white or black.

Adhola: 37 Wachi nyaka ni, ‘Ey’ kosa ‘Be’; gima kalo kenyo man m'inowachi meno wok bongi Ŋatarach.
English: Let what you say be simply ‘Yes’or ‘No’; anything more than this comes from evil.

Adhola: Fuonji kwoŋ chulo kwor
English: Teachin g on revenge

Adhola: “Wityeko winjo chango chon paka owach ni, ‘Waŋ chulo kwor gi waŋ, lak bende gi lak.’
English: “You have heard that it was said, ‘An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth.’

Adhola: To onyo pama awacho ri win ni: ikiri ichul kwor kwoŋ ŋata timo rin marach.
English: But I say to you, Do not resist the one who is evil.

Adhola: Ka nyatoro ogoyo lembin marachuch g'adhoŋ, weyi wogoyi lembin maracham bende.
English: But if anyone slaps you on the right cheek, turn to him the other also.

Adhola: Aka ka nyatoro oterin i kapido ru yenyo sat perin, weyi go woteri kir kot perin bende.
English: And if anyone would sue you and take your tunic, let him have your cloak as well.

Adhola: Aka ka nyatoro oromin wothi mairo achiel, wothi gine mairo aryo.
English: And if anyone forces you to go one mile, go with him two miles.

Adhola: Ka dhano okwayin gimoro, miyi go, aka ka nyatoro mito gimoro mochiko chulo, miyi go.
English: Give to the one who begs from you, and do not refuse the one who would borrow from you.

Adhola: Maro jokwor
English: Loving enemies

Adhola: Wityeko winjo chango chon paka owach ni, ‘Mari mere perin, aka dakere kodi jakwor perin.’
English: You have heard that it was said, ‘You shall love your neighbor and hate your enemy.’

Adhola: To onyo pama awacho ri win ni, mari win jokwor mewin, odoko kwayi win ri joma timo ri win marach, aka nyaka wibino bedo nyithindho pa Baa win mani polo.
English: But I say to you, Love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you,  so that you may be sons of your Father who is in heaven.

Adhola: kole go miyo chieŋ pere lyel ri ji marecho kodi mabeyo ma rom, aka go miyo joma beyo gi joma recho jye koth.
English: For he makes his sun rise on the evil and on the good, and sends rain on the just and on the unjust.

Adhola: Raŋo ma di wigen ni womiy win kemba ka wimaro ji ma bende jomaro win won kende?
English: For if you love those who love you, what reward do you have?
